Award.AwardTitle: Interplay of Transcriptional, Translational Regulatory Mechanisms and Kinetics of an Environmental Response

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT:
Environmental factors change with reproducible characteristics. While changes in oxygen can happen within seconds to minutes, temperature changes occur at a much slower pace over hours to days. Regulatory networks in an organism are tuned through evolution to elicit a response that matches the characteristics of a given environmental factor (e.g. a rapid response to fast changing factors). The overarching hypothesis of this project is that the relative use of regulation at different stages of information processing (transcriptional, post-transcriptional, translational and post-translational) is dictated by the necessary characteristics of an environmental response. In order to test this hypothesis under varying environmental conditions, changes in synthesis and degradation rates will be measured for all transcripts and proteins in strains of Halobacterium salinarum. Building in this proof-of-concept, the research project will systematically investigate interplay across different levels of regulation in the context of specific environmental responses.

BROADER IMPACTS:
Resources: This research will generate fundamental principles of integration across different levels of regulation, and also generate innovative computational and experimental methodology that will be published as well-documented, open-source data and software.

Education: Rapid advances in interdisciplinary science are widening the gap in the way biology is taught and how it is practiced. An award winning high school (HS) education program in the lab is bridging this divide through inquiry-based teaching practices at the grassroots. This ten-year-old program is centered on summer internships for students of disadvantaged backgrounds who are encouraged to apply through numerous partnerships including programs for inner city youth and a UW-based program for advancement of women in science. Educational kits developed through this program have been aligned with state standards, iteratively improved through classroom pilots, and disseminated through professional teacher development to 14 states across the US. In addition to training postdoctoral fellows in systems biology, this project will also develop inquiry-driven, standards-based, HS educational materials. Developed together with local science educators, this novel curriculum module has been requested by teachers and will help students internalize the concepts and methods for using systems biology to understand cellular dynamics in the context of environmental change. These curricula will be aligned with the new Next Generation Science Standards and regularly assess its impact on student learning and career choices through a rigorous evaluation program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF MCB | Interplay of Transcriptional, Translational Regulatory Mechanisms and Kinetics of an Environmental Response

Environmental factors vary with characteristic patterns over a wide range of time scales. Biological systems need to fathom environmental conditions to respond optimally. Certainly, the topology of a regulatory network has significant consequences on cellular phenotype and fitness. Our overarching hypothesis is that the relative usage of transcriptional, post-transcriptional, translational and post-translational regulation is tuned to generate a physiological response that is able to appropriately deal with the unique characteristics of natural environmental change.

We proposed to develop a strategy to systematically integrate across different levels of regulation coherent multiscale models that will help to discover and characterize environment-dependent functions for most regulators including transcription factors, ncRNAs, RNases, and proteases.

In this award, we created a knockout strain library for all regulators of Halobacterium salinarum based on a list of all putative regulatory genes including transcription factors, ribonucleases, RNA-binding proteins, translation factors, and proteases. This library includes 253 strains in total, 189 of which were created for this project. We assayed this strain library for phenotypic effects under various relevant environmental conditions, after developing a novel fitness assessment method based on batch competition that generated highly reproducible results.

Next, we deployed a unique experimental approach to temporally interrogate in a cohesive manner multiple levels of regulation. At several timepoints along the growth curve, we performed in tandem RNA sequencing, ribosome profiling and proteome quantification in H. salinarum. This approach provided a large dataset identifying genome-wide transcriptional information along with active translation. In parallel, we developed a comprehensive spectral library to implement the new, data-independent mass spectrometry technology called sequential window acquisition of all theoretical fragment-ion spectra (SWATH) that supports extensive, label-free quantitation of the proteome. We integrated and analyzed the SWATH-MS results in context of transcriptome and ribosome profiling data resulting in providing evidence that variability in translational subsystems might confer intrinsic regulation of protein synthesis by selectively translating subsets of the transcriptome.

Further, we have developed significant advancements to both cMonkey and Inferelator into an ensemble modeling framework to overcome uncertainties of gene regulatory associations by sampling hundreds to thousands of high quality EGRIN models. Using this ensemble approach, we have demonstrated at single nucleotide resolution, how genome-wide distributions of gene regulatory elements, their spatial organization within promoters, and their environment-dependent activities (i.e. interactions with TFs) dynamically reorganizes a gene regulatory network into physiologically meaningful modular states. We applied our new methods to specific questions regarding environmental responses of multiple organisms of the 3 domains of life, from H. salinarum to Bacteria like Escherichia coli and CMNR bacteria to Eukaryotes like Chlamydomonas reinhardtii and ultimately, human. These results prove that our method is generalizable and able to reveal fundamentally new biological insights in disparate, even understudied organisms.

Broader impacts

We developed user-friendly, inquiry-driven, standards-based Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) education materials to teach middle and high school educators and students how to research real world issues such as food security and environmental sustainability. These activities allow users to understand how a complex system can be modeled as a network of interacting parts. These resources also teach educators and students how to build experimental systems to test hypotheses related to these issues. We directly trained hundreds of teachers in person to use these resources and also provided online training and assistance to hundreds more. We also created a new, ambassador internship model to address the high demand of our summer high school internships. Through our immersive internship experiences and ambassador program, we provided extensive experiences for 3 teachers and 30 high school students. We also partnered with external groups to better leverage curriculum, internships and training experiences, and technology development to provide and share data—including an interactive app—on top of resources and best practices. All materials are freely available and will continue to optimized and disseminated via our website (http://see.systemsbiology.net).
